newsitem.title: GERMANY: German health insurers mull invoice fraud action.
newsitem.headline: German health insurers mull invoice fraud action.

text.p: German private health insurers should join with doctors' associations to set up a settlement company for private practice invoices to force out companies using doubtful business practices.
This was proposed by Dr Jan Boetius, management board chairman of Deutsche Krankenversicherung (DKV) in Cologne, on Monday.
A standardised and tested process for dealing with private bills for doctors would simplify the payment process, said Boetius.

At the same time it would make more difficult the manipulation practised by some settlement companies, of which private health insurers frequently complain. A few weeks ago, DKV brought charges of invoice fraud against the Saarbruecken company Unimed.
Boetius is convinced that such an offer would quickly be accepted by doctors, because it would reduce their paperwork considerably.
"In addition, doctors would receive their money more rapidly, since many plausibility checks which we now make on invoices would be dropped."
Boetius said the project is at a very early stage, but he is confident of obtaining agreement from the medical profession.
The legal form which the new settlement company would take has not yet been decided.

"I would imagine that we cannot choose a public-law system, because then the private health insurers could not take part. And with their knowledge of invoice preparation, they have to be included. It will probably not be a co-operative, but most likely a limited company."
